column2: not to be confused with the Pennsylvania Dutch
column3: are Americans of Dutch descent whose ancestors came from the Netherlands in the recent or distant past. Whether or not it is intentional
column4: they usually maintain connections with their Dutch heritage
column5: by having
column6: for example
column7: a Dutch surname or belonging to a Dutch community group. Dutch settlement in the Americas started in 1613 with New Amsterdam
column8: which was exchanged with the English for Suriname at the Treaty of Breda (1667) and renamed to New York City. The English split the Dutch colony of New Netherland into two pieces
column9: and named them New York and New Jersey. Further waves of immigration occurred in the 19th and 20th centuries.

column1: == Dutch presence in the present-day territory of the United States ==

column2: the Dutch government chartered the Dutch East India Company (Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie
column3: VOC). It sent explorers under the command of Henry Hudson who arrived in 1609 and mapped what is now known as the Hudson River. Their initial goal was to find an alternative route to Asia
column4: but they found good farmland and plenty of wildlife instead.

column1: The earliest Dutch settlement was built around 1613
column2: it consisted of a number of small huts built by the crew of the "Tijger" (Tiger)
column3: a Dutch ship under the command of Captain Adriaen Block which had caught fire while sailing on the Hudson in the winter of 1613. The ship was lost and Block and his crew established a camp ashore. In the spring
column4: Block and his men did some explorations along the coast of Long Island. Block Island still bears his name. Finally
column5: they were sighted and rescued by another Dutch ship and the settlement was abandoned.

column1: Dutch trade in the New York area led to the establishment of trade posts as early as 1613. Permanent settlers arrived in 1617 at what is now Albany
column2: New York. New Amsterdam was settled in 1625. In 1629
column3: Dutch officials tried to expand the northern colony through a plan that promised "Liberties and Exemptions" to anyone who would ship fifty colonists to America at his own expense. Anyone who did so would be allowed to buy a stretch of land along the Hudson River from the Dutch West India Company of about twelve miles
column4: extending as far inland as the owner wanted. The landowners were called patroons and had complete jurisdiction over their domains as well as extensive trading privileges. They also received these rights in perpetuity. That was a form of feudalism
column5: which had vanished in the Dutch Republic but was introduced in North America. The Patroonships were not a success; by 1635
column6: the Dutch West India Company had bought back four of the five patroonships originally registered in Amsterdam.

column1: The Native Americans were no longer consulted or offered/asked to sell their lands. The Dutch were confronted with a new phenomenon
column2: Native American raids
column3: since the local tribes had now realized that the Dutch were not simply visitors but people set to settle their land.

column1: The Dutch realized that they had gone with the wrong approach as they offered great privileges to wealthy
column2: not poor
column3: citizens. It was not until 1656 that the Dutch state abandoned its passivity and decided to actively support New Netherland. The Dutch state issued a proclamation
column4: which stated that "all mechanics and farmers who can prove their ability to earn a living here shall receive free passage for themselves
column5: their wives and children".

column1: Although the Dutch were in control
column2: only about half the settlers were ethnically Dutch (the other half consisted mainly of Walloons
column3: Germans and French Huguenots as well as new England Yankees). Manhattan grew increasingly multicultural. In 1664
column4: the English seized the colony and renamed it New York. The Dutch briefly recaptured the colony in 1673
column5: but during peace talks with the English
column6: they decided to trade it in 1674 for Suriname in South America
column7: which was more profitable.

column1: In the hundred years of British rule that followed the change of ownership of New Netherland
column2: Dutch immigration to America came to an almost complete standstill.

column1: While the Netherlands was a small country
column2: the Dutch Empire was quite large so emigrants leaving the mother country had a wide variety of choices. New Amsterdam was not high on their list
column3: especially because of the Native American risk. The major Dutch cities were centers of high culture
column4: but they still sent immigrants. Most new arrivals were farmers from remote villages who
column5: on arrival
column6: in America scattered into widely separated villages with little contact with one another. Even inside a settlement
column7: different Dutch groups had minimal interaction. With very few new arrivals
column8: the result was an increasingly traditional system cut off from the forces for change. The people maintained their popular culture
column9: revolving around their language and their Calvinist religion. The Dutch brought along their own folklore
column10: most famously Sinterklaas (the foundation of the modern-day Santa Claus) and created their own as in The Legend of Sleepy Hollow. They maintained their distinctive clothing
column11: and food preferences and introduced some new foods to America

column2: the rich Dutch families in Albany and New York City emulated the English elite and purchased English furniture
column3: silverware
column4: crystal
column5: and jewelry. They were proud of their language
column6: which was strongly reinforced by the church
column7: but they were much slower than the Yankees in setting up schools for their children. They finally set up Queens College (now Rutgers University) in New Jersey
column8: but it quickly became anglicized. They never attempted to start newspapers; they published no books and only a handful of religious tracts annually. Pietist leader Theodorus Jacobus Frelinghuysen (1691 – 1747) launched a series of revivals that challenge the mainstream church's emphasis on sacraments. Church buildings increasingly followed English rather than historic Dutch models. Politically
column9: however
column10: there was a strong anti-British sentiment that led most of the Dutch to support the American Revolution. One famous Dutch folk hero was Rip Van Winkle
column11: characterized by being absurdly old-fashioned and out of date
column12: which aimed to instill the establishment of an American culture distinct from British culture. Most farmers focused on providing subsistence for their families; about a third were chiefly oriented to market prices.Dutch Quakers came to the Philadelphia area in response to the appeal of William Penn. Penn
column13: himself a Dutch Briton (his mother being from Rotterdam)
column14: had paid three visits to the Netherlands

column2: large numbers of Dutch farmers
column3: forced by high taxes and low wages
column4: started immigrating to America. They mainly settled down in the Midwest
column5: especially Michigan
column6: Illinois and Iowa. In the 1840s
column7: Calvinist immigrants desiring more religious freedom immigrated. West Michigan in particular has become associated with Dutch American culture
column8: and the highly conservative influence of the Dutch Reformed Church
column9: centering on the cities of Holland and (to a lesser extent) Grand Rapids.

column2: initially encouraged in the 1840s by Father Theodore J. van den Broek
column3: emigrated from southern Netherlands to form communities in Wisconsin
column4: primarily to Little Chute
column5: Hollandtown
column6: and the outlying farming communities. Whole families and even neighborhoods left for America. Most of these early emigrants were from villages near Uden
column7: including Zeeland
column8: Boekel
column9: Mill
column11: many Protestant agrarian emigrants to Michigan and Iowa were drawn from Groningen
column13: and Zeeland; areas known for their clay soils.The Dutch economy of the 1840s was stagnant and much of the motivation to emigrate was economic rather than political or religious. The emigrants were not poor
column15: expenses and land purchase in America would have been substantial. They were not
column17: affluent and many would have been risking most of their wealth on the chance of economic improvement. There were also political pressures at the time that favored mass emigrations of Catholics.

column1: A significant number of Dutchmen emigrating to the United States after World War II arrived from Indonesia via the Netherlands. After Indonesia
column2: formerly known as the Dutch East Indies
column3: gained independence its Indo-European (Eurasian) population known as Indies Dutchmen (Dutch: Indische Nederlanders) repatriated to the Netherlands. Around 60
column4: 000 continued their diaspora to the United States. This particular group is also known as Dutch-Indonesians
column5: Indonesian-Dutch
column6: or Amerindos.

column1: Nine tenths of the so called Europeans (in the Dutch East Indies) are the offspring of whites married to native women. These mixed people are called Indo-Europeans... They have formed the backbone of officialdom. In general they feel the same loyalty to Holland as do the white Netherlanders. They have full rights as Dutch citizens and they are Christians and follow Dutch customs. This group has suffered more than any other during the Japanese occupation. Official U.S. Army publication for the benefit of G.I.'s

These Dutch Indos mainly entered the United States under legislative refugee measures and were sponsored by Christian organizations such as the Church World Service and the Catholic Relief Services. An accurate count of Indo immigrants is not available
column2: as the U.S. Census classified people according to their self-determined ethnic affiliation. The Indos could have therefore been included in overlapping categories of "country of origin"
column3: "other Asians
column4: total foreign"
column5: "mixed parentage"
column6: "total foreign-born" and "foreign mother tongue". However the Indos that settled in the United States via the legislative refugee measures number at least 25
column7: 000 people.The original post-war refugee legislation of 1948
column8: already adhering to a strict "affidavit of support" policy
column9: was still maintaining a color bar making it difficult for Indos to emigrate to the USA. By 1951 American consulates in the Netherlands registered 33
column10: 500 requests and had waiting times of 3 to 5 years. Also the Walter-McCarren Act of 1953 adhered to the traditional American policy of minimizing immigrants from Asia. The yearly quota for Indonesia was limited to a 100 visas
column11: even though Dutch foreign affairs attempted to profile Indos as refugees from the alleged pro-communist Sukarno administration.The 1953 flood disaster in the Netherlands resulted in the Refugee Relief Act including a slot for 15
column12: 000 ethnic Dutch that had at least 50% European blood (one year later loosened to Dutch citizens with at least two Dutch grandparents) and an immaculate legal and political track record. In 1954 only 187 visas were actually granted. Partly influenced by the anti-Western rhetoric and policies of the Sukarno administration the anti-communist senator Francis E. Walter pleaded for a second term of the Refugee Relief Act in 1957 and an additional slot of 15
column14: the Pastore–Walter Immigration Act for the relief of certain distressed aliens was passed allowing for a one off acceptance of 10
column15: 000 Dutchmen from Indonesia (excluding the regular annual quota of 3
column16: 136 visas). It was hoped however that only 10% of these Dutch refugees would in fact be racially mixed Indos and the American embassy in The Hague was frustrated with the fact that Canada
column17: where ethnic profiling was even stricter
column18: was getting the full-blooded Dutch and the United States was getting Dutch "all rather heavily dark". Still in 1960 senators Pastore and Walter managed to get a second two-year term for their act which was used by a great number of Dutch Indos.

column1: == Dutch influence on the United States ==

column1: In 1657 the clash between Peter Stuyvesant and Quakers led by John Bowne resulted in the Flushing Remonstrance which served as the basis for religious freedom in America.
Dutch settlers and their descendants in the colonies played active roles in the American Revolution and the formation of the United States
column2: most especially descendants of the Schuyler family and the Van Cortlandt family. Dutch American signers of the Declaration of Independence included Philip Livingston and Lewis Morris
column3: both from New York. Generals for the patriots included Philip Schuyler
column4: Peter Gansevoort
column5: and Major General James Morgan Jr. from New Jersey. On the side working with the British included New York City Mayor David Mathews (a cousin of General Schuyler)
column6: Major General Oliver Delancey and Brigadier General Cortlandt Skinner (both Schuyler family descendants).

column1: During the American war of Independence the Dutch were active allies of the American revolutionaries. From the island of Sint Eustatius they gave the Thirteen Colonies one of the few opportunities to acquire arms. In 1778
column2: British Lord Stormont claimed in parliament that "if Sint Eustatius had sunk into the sea three years before
column3: the United Kingdom would already have dealt with George Washington".

column1: The Dutch were the first to salute the flag and
column2: therefore
column3: the first to acknowledge the independence of the United States on November 16

column2: also known as the "Great Land Acquisition"
column3: is often seen as one of the most important events in American history after the Declaration of Independence. At the time it had a total cost of $15 million
column4: and it was financed in three ways. First by a down payment of $3 million
column5: in gold by the U.S. government
column6: followed by two loans
column7: one by the London-based Barings Bank
column8: and one by the Amsterdam-based Hope Bank. The original receipt still exists and is currently property of the Dutch ING Group
column9: which has its headquarters in Amsterdam.

column1: == Dutch language and Dutch names in North America ==
The first Dutch settlers lived in small isolated communities
column2: and as a consequence were barely exposed to English. As the Dutch lost their own colonies in North America to the British
column3: the Dutch settlers increasingly were exposed to other immigrants and their languages and the Dutch language gradually started to disappear.

column2: Archibald Laidlie preached the first English sermon to the Dutch Reformed congregation in New York City. Ten years later English was introduced in the schools. In Kingston
column3: Dutch was used in church as late as 1808. A few years before
column4: a traveler had reported that on Long Island and along the North River in Albany
column5: Dutch was still the lingua franca of the elderly.Francis Adrian van der Kemp
column6: who came to the United States as a refugee in 1788
column7: wrote that his wife was able to converse in Dutch with the wives of Alexander Hamilton and General George Clinton. In 1847
column8: immigrants from the Netherlands were welcomed in Dutch by the Reverend Isaac Wyckoff upon their arrival in New York. Wyckoff himself was a descendant of one of the first settlers in Rensselaerswyck
column9: who had learned to speak English at school.

column1: Until recently many communities in New Jersey adhered to the tradition of a monthly church service in Dutch. As late as 1905
column2: Dutch was still heard among the old people in the Ramapo Valley of that state. Dutch is still spoken by the elderly and their children in Western Michigan. It was not until 1910 that Roseland Christian School in Chicago switched to an English curriculum from Dutch.In the first half of the twentieth century
column3: the Dutch language was hardly spoken in North America
column4: with the exception of first generation Dutch immigrants. The marks of the Dutch heritage - in language
column5: in reference to historical Dutch people (for example Stuyvesant) and in reference to Dutch places (for example Brooklyn which stems from Breukelen) - can still be seen. There are about 35 Dutch restaurants and bakeries in the United States
column6: most of them founded in the 20th century.New York City for example has many originally Dutch street and place names which range from Coney Island and Brooklyn to Wall Street and Broadway. And up the river in New York State Piermont
column7: Orangeburg
column8: Blauvelt and Haverstraw
column9: just to name a few places. In the Hudson Valley region there are many places and waterways whose names incorporate the word -kill

column1: There are also some words in American-English that are of Dutch origin
column2: like "cookie" (koekje) and "boss" (baas). And in some family names a couple of Dutch characteristics still remain. Like (a) the prefix "van" (as in Martin Van Buren)
column3: (b) the prefix "de"(/"der"/"des"/"den") (as in Jared DeVries)
column4: (c) a combination of the two "van de ..." (as in Robert J. Van de Graaff)
column5: or (d) "ter"/"te"("ten")
column6: which mean respectively (a) "of" (possessive or locative)
column7: (b) "the" (definite article)
column8: (c) "of the..." and (d) "at the" ("of the"/"in the") (locative).

column1: Similarities between Dutch and English are abundant. Examples include the article "the" (de in Dutch)
column2: the words "book" (boek)
column3: "house" (huis)
column4: "pen" (pen)
column5: and
column6: "street" (straat)
column7: among others. Dutch and English are both part of the West Germanic language group and share several aspects. Adaptation of place names between the languages is common
column8: as was the case of New York
column9: where several landmarks like Conyne Eylandt  (Rabbit Island) became more suitable to Anglophones (Coney Island).

column1: Contact between other languages also created various creoles with Dutch as the base language. Two examples

column3: are now extinct. This is possibly due to the ease of transition from Dutch to English

Maarten Schmidt pioneered the research of quasars. Astronomer Gerard Kuiper discovered two new moons in our solar system and predicted the existence of the Kuiper belt
column3: which is named in his honor. Popular astronomer Bart J. Bok won the Klumpke-Roberts Award in 1982 and the Bruce Medal in 1977. Jan Schilt invented the Schilt photometer.

column2: Hall of Fame baseball player and two-time World Series champion Bert Blyleven gained fame for his curveball. Earl Bascom was a Hall of Fame rodeo champion known as the "father of modern rodeo."
Albertus van Raalte was a Reformed Church of America pastor who led the Dutch immigrants who founded the city of Holland
column3: Michigan in 1846. Louis Berkhof
column4: a Reformed systematic theologian
column5: is greatly studied today in seminaries and Bible colleges. Herman Hoeksema
column6: a theologian
column7: was instrumental in the series of events that precipitated the creation of the Protestant Reformed Church. Prominent Christian author Lewis B. Smedes wrote Forgive and Forget
column8: an influential work discussing a religious view on sexuality and forgiveness. Menno Simons (1496 – 31 January 1561) was a former Catholic priest from the Friesland region of the Netherlands who became an influential Anabaptist religious leader. Simons was a contemporary of the Protestant Reformers and it is from his name that his followers became known as Mennonites.
